text:
Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion,

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

While I have not personally experienced period shaming or period poverty, I have witnessed such incidents first hand when I attended high school, and middle school as well. Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

While I have not personally experienced period shaming or period poverty, I have witnessed such incidents first hand when I attended high school, and middle school as well. I think it is a negative outcome for female students, that personally affects them psychologically, and for a long period of time. Ideally , girls should be able to buy whatever products they might need for their menstruation without any worry.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

While I have not personally experienced period shaming or period poverty, I have witnessed such incidents first hand when I attended high school, and middle school as well. I think it is a negative outcome for female students, that personally affects them psychologically, and for a long period of time. Ideally , girls should be able to buy and receive whatever products they might need for their menstruation without any worry. Schools should step in and help this natural process of life that female students go through. For many students, it can be a daunting endeavor to understand the process of which pads or tampons to buy. For others, poverty can affect whether they can buy menstrual process on a constant and regular basis.

I think it is a negative outcome for female students, that personally affects them psychologically, and for a long period of time. Ideally , girls should be able to buy and receive whatever products they might need for their menstruation without any worry. Schools should step in and help this natural process of life that female students go through. For many students, it can be a daunting endeavor to understand the process of which pads or tampons to buy. For others, poverty can affect whether they can buy menstrual process on a constant and regular basis. Thus , providing pads and tampons can help limit the period shaming, and period poverty that female students are regularly subject to.

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

While I have not personally experienced period shaming or period poverty, I have witnessed such incidents first hand when I attended high school, and middle school as well. I think it is a negative outcome for female students, that personally affects them psychologically, and for a long period of time. Ideally , girls should be able to buy and receive whatever products they might need for their menstruation without any worry. Schools should step in and help this natural process of life that female students go through. For many students, it can be a daunting endeavor to understand the process of which pads or tampons to buy. For others, poverty can affect whether they can buy menstrual process on a constant and regular basis. Thus, providing free pads and tampons can help limit the period shaming, and period poverty that female students are regularly subject to.

Tampons and Pads are much similar to Band-Aids and similar items provided by the school. For example, they are hygienic items like soap and toilet paper, intended to make the user clean and avoid appearing unhygienic. Like Band-Aids, they stop bleeding for a period of time, as long as one continues to wear them, and have to be changed out every while.

While I have not personally experienced period shaming or period poverty, I have witnessed such incidents first hand when I attended high school, and middle school as well. I think it is a negative outcome for female students, that personally affects them psychologically, and for a long period of time. Ideally , girls should be able to buy and receive whatever products they might need for their menstruation without any worry. Schools should step in and help this natural process of life that female students go through. For many students, it can be a daunting endeavor to understand the process of which pads or tampons to buy. For others, poverty can affect whether they can buy menstrual process on a constant and regular basis. Thus, providing free pads and tampons can help limit the period shaming, and period poverty that female students are regularly subject to.

Tampons and Pads are much similar to Band-Aids and similar items provided by the school. For example, they are hygienic items like soap and toilet paper, intended to make the user clean and avoid appearing unhygienic. Like Band-Aids, they stop bleeding for a period of time and as long as one continues to wear them, and they have to be changed out every while. I am sure that students would appreciate seeing them in the school, just as they would any other supply readily available in school.

Schools should step in and help this natural process of life that female students go through. For many students, it can be a daunting endeavor to understand the process of which pads or tampons to buy. Thus, providing free pads and tampons can help limit the period shaming, and period poverty that female students are regularly subject to.

For example, they are hygienic items like soap and toilet paper, intended to make the user clean and avoid appearing unhygienic. Like Band-Aids, they stop bleeding for a period of time and as long as one continues to wear them, and they have to be changed out every while. I am sure that students would appreciate seeing them in the school, just as they would any other supply readily available in school. However, unlike Band-Aids and other items, their ought to be a better sense of privacy for the students requesting tampons and pads.

While I have not personally experienced period shaming or period poverty, I have witnessed such incidents first hand when I attended high school, and middle school as well. I think it is a negative outcome for female students, that personally affects them psychologically, and for a long period of time. Ideally , girls should be able to buy and receive whatever products they might need for their menstruation without any worry. Schools should step in and help this natural process of life that female students go through. For many students, it can be a daunting endeavor to understand the process of which pads or tampons to buy. For others, poverty can affect whether they can buy menstrual process on a constant and regular basis. Thus, providing free pads and tampons can help limit the period shaming, and period poverty that female students are regularly subject to.

Tampons and Pads are much similar to Band-Aids and similar items provided by the school. For example, they are hygienic items like soap and toilet paper, intended to make the user clean and avoid appearing unhygienic. Like Band-Aids, they stop bleeding for a period of time and as long as one continues to wear them, and they have to be changed out every while. I am sure that students would appreciate seeing them in the school, just as they would any other supply readily available in school. However, unlike Band-Aids and other items, their ought to be a better sense of privacy for the students requesting tampons and pads. For example, there should not be any announcement in an auditorium or over the intercom that the student need pads.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

While I have not personally experienced period shaming or period poverty, I have witnessed such incidents first hand when I attended high school, and middle school as well. I think it is a negative outcome for female students, that personally affects them psychologically, and for a long period of time. Ideally , girls should be able to buy and receive whatever products they might need for their menstruation without any worry. Schools should step in and help this natural process of life that female students go through. For many students, it can be a daunting endeavor to understand the process of which pads or tampons to buy. For others, poverty can affect whether they can buy menstrual process on a constant and regular basis. Thus, providing free pads and tampons can help limit the period shaming, and period poverty that female students are regularly subject to.

Tampons and Pads are much similar to Band-Aids and similar items provided by the school. For example, they are hygienic items like soap and toilet paper, intended to make the user clean and avoid appearing unhygienic. Like Band-Aids, they stop bleeding for a period of time and as long as one continues to wear them, and they have to be changed out every while. I am sure that students would appreciate seeing them in the school, just as they would any other supply readily available in school. However, unlike Band-Aids and other items, their ought to be a better sense of privacy for the students requesting tampons and pads. For example, there should not be any announcement in an auditorium or over the intercom that the student need pads or tampons, and ideally the school would not keep a record of such, allowing the students to remain anonymous when requesting the pads and receiving them. Through that, they can receive the tampons and pads they require, without feeling judged for doing so and potentially being stigmatized for what is effectively a natural and commonplace occurrence.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

While I have not personally experienced period shaming or period poverty, I have witnessed such incidents first hand when I attended high school, and middle school as well. I think it is a negative outcome for female students, that personally affects them psychologically, and for a long period of time. Ideally , girls should be able to buy and receive whatever products they might need for their menstruation without any worry. Schools should step in and help this natural process of life that female students go through. For many students, it can be a daunting endeavor to understand the process of which pads or tampons to buy. For others, poverty can affect whether they can buy menstrual process on a constant and regular basis. Thus, providing free pads and tampons can help limit the period shaming, and period poverty that female students are regularly subject to.

Tampons and Pads are much similar to Band-Aids and similar items provided by the school. For example, they are hygienic items like soap and toilet paper, intended to make the user clean and avoid appearing unhygienic. Like Band-Aids, they stop bleeding for a period of time and as long as one continues to wear them, and they have to be changed out every while. I am sure that students would appreciate seeing them in the school, just as they would any other supply readily available in school. However, unlike Band-Aids and other items, their ought to be a better sense of privacy for the students requesting tampons and pads. For example, there should not be any announcement in an auditorium or over the intercom that the student need pads or tampons, and ideally the school would not keep a record of such, allowing the students to remain anonymous when requesting the pads and receiving them. Through that, they can receive the tampons and pads they require, without feeling judged for doing so and potentially being stigmatized for what is effectively a natural and commonplace occurrence. 

Schools ought to be a place where students feel comfortable and able to learn and develop as individuals. Providing tampons and pads are a critically way for schools to do so for female students. By offering them in a private and respectful way, schools can give comfort and stability for students undergoing their period, that otherwise might be judged and ridiculed for lacking access to such supplies.
